summary: This document appears to be notes from a December 3, 2021 call with expert witness Gail Goodman discussing memory science, particularly in relation to child sexual abuse (CSA) victims and false memory research. It critiques Elizabeth Loftus's work and asserts that false memories of CSA are not scientifically proven to be prevalent.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.context: Participated in a call to discuss her expertise on memory, particularly in relation to child sexual abuse victims and forensic interviews. Her work has been cited by the Supreme Court.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: Referenced as a researcher whose work on false memory is discussed and critiqued, including a study involving interrogation and photo identification errors.

connections.description: Goodman's expertise and opinions are presented in contrast to Loftus's research on false memory, indicating a professional/academic relationship within the field of memory science.

events.title: Expert Consultation Call
events.description: A call was held with Gail Goodman to discuss her expert testimony on memory, focusing on victim expression during forensic interviews and the science of false memories related to child sexual abuse.

keyFacts: Gail Goodman's expertise includes the relationship between memory and the legal system, and her work has been cited by the Supreme Court.
The document discusses the 'adolescent bump' in autobiographical memory literature and notes that false memories of child sexual abuse (CSA) are not scientifically proven to be prevalent.

Elizabeth Loftus's research on false memory is referenced, including a specific study involving interrogation and photo identification errors, but Goodman critiques the generality of Loftus's claims regarding CSA.
